natural problem: Compute the product of all the roots of the equation \[\sqrt{5 | x | + 8} = \sqrt{x^2 - 16}.\]
natural solution: Squaring both sides, we have $5|x|+8=x^2-16,$ or $5|x|=x^2-24.$ From here, we take cases on the sign of $x$: If $x \ge 0,$ then we have $5x=x^2-24,$ so \[0=x^2-5x-24 = (x-8)(x+3),\]which has roots $x=8$ and $x=-3.$ However, we assumed in this case that $x \ge 0,$ so we only get the solution $x=8.$
If $x < 0,$ then we have $-5x=x^2-24,$ so \[0=x^2+5x-24=(x+8)(x-3),\]which has roots $x=-8$ and $x=3.$ However, we assumed in this case that $x \le 0,$ so we only get the solution $x=-8.$
We can check that both $x=8$ and $x=-8$ satisfy the original equation, so the product of the roots is $8 \cdot -8 = \boxed{-64}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = sqrt (5 * abs x + 8)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = sqrt (x powr 2 - 16)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. f x = g x"
shows  "prod_list (roots_of f) = -64"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the product of all the roots of the equation \[\sqrt{5 | x | + 8} = \sqrt{x^2 - 16}.\] The final Answer is -64
 ### Proof
 Squaring both sides, we have $5|x|+8=x^2-16,$ or $5|x|=x^2-24.$ From here, we take cases on the sign of $x$: If $x \ge 0,$ then we have $5x=x^2-24,$ so \[0=x^2-5x-24 = (x-8)(x+3),\]which has roots $x=8$ and $x=-3.$ However, we assumed in this case that $x \ge 0,$ so we only get the solution $x=8.$
 If $x < 0,$ then we have $-5x=x^2-24,$ so \[0=x^2+5x-24=(x+8)(x-3),\]which has roots $x=-8$ and $x=3.$ However, we assumed in this case that $x \le 0,$ so we only get the solution $x=-8.$
 We can check that both $x=8$ and $x=-8$ satisfy the original equation, so the product of the roots is $8 \cdot -8 = \boxed{-64}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = sqrt (5 * abs x + 8)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = sqrt (x powr 2 - 16)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. f x = g x"
shows  "prod_list (roots_of f) = -64"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given two functions $f(x) = \sqrt{5|x| + 8}$ and $g(x) = \sqrt{x^2 - 16}$, it is known that $f(x) = g(x)$ for all $x$. Find the product of all roots of the function $f(x)$. The final answer is $-64$.

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "sqrt (5 * abs x + 8) = sqrt (x powr 2 - 16)"
and h1 : "x \<noteq> 0"
shows  "prod_list (roots (\<lambda>x. sqrt (5 * abs x + 8) - sqrt (x powr 2 - 16))) = -64"

 We can check that both $x=8$ and $x=-8$ satisfy the original equation, so the product of the roots is $8 \cdot -8 = \boxed{-64}.$
 *)

fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "sqrt (5 * abs x + 8) = sqrt (x powr 2 - 16)"
and h1 : "x \<noteq> 0"
shows  "prod_list (roots (\<lambda>x. sqrt (5 * abs x + 8) - sqrt (x powr 2 - 16))) = -64"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = sqrt (5 * abs x + 8)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = sqrt (x powr 2 - 16)"
and h2 : "P x = Q x"
shows  "prod_list (roots P) = -64"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the product of all the roots of the equation \[\sqrt{5 | x | + 8} = \sqrt{x^2 - 16}.\] The final Answer is -64
 ### Proof

 We can check that both $x=8$ and $x=-8$ satisfy the original equation, so the product of the roots is $8 \cdot -8 = \boxed{-64}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = sqrt (5 * abs x + 8)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = sqrt (x powr 2 - 16)"
and h2 : "P x = Q x"
shows  "prod_list (roots P) = -64"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given two functions $P(x) = \sqrt{5|x| + 8}$ and $Q(x) = \sqrt{x^2 - 16}$, find the value of $x$ such that $P(x) = Q(x)$. Compute the product of all roots of $P$. The final answer is $-64$.
